The final step is to transform the Logit coefficients into non-negative integers

This algorithm is the Logit analogue to the familiar R -based stepwise with least-
squares regression. It differs from na�ve stepwise in that the criteria for selecting
indicators include not only statistical accuracy but also judgment and non-statistical
factors. The use of non-statistical criteria can improve robustness through time and

FIELD2: helps ensure that indicators are simple and make sense to users.

The sum of scorecard points for a household is called the score. For Ethiopia
scores range from 0 (most likely below a poverty line) to 100 (least likely below a
poverty line). While higher scores indicate less likelihood of being below a poverty line
the scores themselves have only relative units. For example
double the likelihood of being above a poverty line.

8. Estimates of changes in group poverty rates over time
The change in a group�s poverty rate between two points in time is estimated as
the change in the average poverty likelihood of the households in the group. With data

FIELD2: this paper cannot estimate changes over time

Simple Poverty Scorecard: nor can it present sample-size formula. Nevertheless

FIELD3: pro-poor organizations can apply the scorecard to

Simple Poverty Scorecard: collect their own data and measure change through time.
Scoring can estimate change. Of course
FIELD2: poverty could get better or worse

Simple Poverty Scorecard: scoring does not indicate what caused change. This point is often forgotten or confused
so it bears repeating: poverty scoring simply estimates change

FIELD2: indicate the reason for the change. In particular

Simple Poverty Scorecard: program participation requires knowing what would have happened to participants if
assumptions or a control group that resembles participants in all ways except

FIELD2: poverty scoring can help estimate program impact

Simple Poverty Scorecard: only if there is some way to know what would have happened in the absence of the
program. And that information must come from somewhere beyond poverty scoring.
Even measuring simple change usually requires assuming that the population is
constant over time and that program drop-outs do not differ from non-drop-outs.

Simple Poverty Scorecard: When a program uses poverty scoring for targeting
below a cut-off are labeled targeted and treated�for program purposes�as if they are
below a given poverty line. Households with scores above a cut-off are labeled non-
targeted and treated�for program purposes�as if they are above a given poverty line.
There is a distinction between targeting status (scoring at or below a targeting
cut-off) and poverty status (expenditure below a poverty line). Poverty status is a fact
that depends on whether expenditure is below a poverty line as directly measured by a

FIELD2: targeting status is a program�s policy choice that depends on a cut-

Simple Poverty Scorecard: off and on an indirect estimate from a scorecard.
Targeting is successful when households truly below a poverty line are targeted
(inclusion) and when households truly above a poverty line are not targeted (exclusion).

FIELD3: and targeting is unsuccessful when households truly

Simple Poverty Scorecard: below a poverty line are not targeted (undercoverage) or when households truly above a
poverty line are targeted (leakage). Figure 11 depicts these four possible targeting
outcomes. Targeting accuracy varies by cut-off; a higher cut-off has better inclusion

FIELD2: while a lower cut-off has better exclusion (but higher

Simple Poverty Scorecard: A program should weigh these trade-offs when setting a cut-off. A formal way to
do this is to assign net benefits�based on a program�s values and mission�to each of
the four possible targeting outcomes and then to choose the cut-off that maximizes total
Figure 12 shows the distribution of households by targeting outcome for the
Ethiopia scorecard applied to the validation sample. For an example cut-off of 15�19
outcomes for the USD1.25/day 2005 PPP line applied to the validation sample are:
?  Inclusion:         7.4 percent are below the line and correctly targeted
?  Undercoverage:  19.9 percent are below the line and mistakenly not targeted
?  Leakage:           5.4 percent are above the line and mistakenly targeted
?  Exclusion:         67.4 percent are above the line and correctly not targeted
Increasing the cut-off to 20�24 improves inclusion and undercoverage but
?  Inclusion:         12.5 percent are below the line and correctly targeted
?  Undercoverage:  14.7 percent are below the line and mistakenly not targeted
?  Leakage:           10.8 percent are above the line and mistakenly targeted
?  Exclusion:         62.0 percent are above the line and correctly not targeted
Which cut-off is preferred depends on total net benefit. If each targeting outcome
has a per-household benefit or cost
FIELD2: then the total net benefit for a given cut-off is:

Simple Poverty Scorecard: Benefit per household correctly included       x Households correctly included            �
Cost per household mistakenly not covered  x  Households mistakenly not covered  �
Cost per household mistakenly leaked           x Households mistakenly leaked             +
Benefit per household correctly excluded       x  Households correctly excluded.
?  Assign benefits and costs to possible outcomes
FIELD2: based on its values and mission

Simple Poverty Scorecard: ?  Tally total net benefits for each cut-off using Figure 12 for a given poverty line
?  Select the cut-off with the highest total net benefit
The most difficult step is assigning benefits and costs to targeting outcomes. Any
program that uses targeting�with or without scoring�should thoughtfully consider
how it values successful inclusion or exclusion versus errors of undercoverage and
leakage. It is healthy to go through a process of thinking explicitly and intentionally
about how possible targeting outcomes are valued.

This paper presents the Simple Poverty Scorecard . Pro-poor organizations in
Ethiopia can use it to estimate the likelihood that a household has expenditure below a

FIELD2: to estimate the poverty rate of a group of households at a point in
and to estimate changes in the poverty rate of a group of households between two

Simple Poverty Scorecard: points in time. The scorecard can also be used for targeting.
The scorecard is inexpensive to use and can be understood by non-specialists. It
is designed to be practical for local pro-poor organizations who want to improve how
they monitor and manage their social performance in order to speed up their
The scorecard is built with a sub-sample of data from the 2004/5 HICE and 2004

FIELD3: and calibrated to four poverty lines

Simple Poverty Scorecard: Accuracy and precision are reported for estimates of households� poverty

FIELD2: groups� poverty rates at a point in time
the scorecard�s estimates of changes in poverty rates are not

Simple Poverty Scorecard: the same as estimates of program impact. Targeting accuracy is also reported.
When the scorecard is applied to the validation sample
between estimates versus true poverty rates for groups of households at a point in time
is always less than 2.1 percentage points and averages�across the four poverty lines�
these differences is +/�0.6 percentage points or less

FIELD2: programs can use the results reported here to select a cut-off that

Simple Poverty Scorecard: Although the statistical technique is innovative

FIELD2: the design of the scorecard here focuses on transparency and ease-of-use.
a perfectly accurate scorecard is worthless if programs feel so daunted by its

Simple Poverty Scorecard: complexity or its cost that they do not even try to use it. For this reason

FIELD2: using 11 indicators that are inexpensive to collect and that are

Simple Poverty Scorecard: straightforward to verify. Points are all zeros or positive integers
0 (most likely below a poverty line) to 100 (least likely below a poverty line). Scores are
related to poverty likelihoods via simple look-up tables
likewise simple to apply. The design attempts to facilitate adoption by helping
managers understand and trust scoring and by allowing non-specialists to generate

FIELD2: the poverty scorecard is a practical

Simple Poverty Scorecard: in Ethiopia to monitor poverty rates
FIELD2: track changes in poverty rates over time
